awd_titl_txt: An Approach to Robust Performance Analysis Using Optimal Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to investigate a comprehensive set of tools to enable robust performance analysis and decision making by building a framework which systematically evaluates the impact of modeling errors. The general philosophy of this research is as follows. Stochastic models are used virtually everywhere and many of these models are convenient because they can be easily calibrated and/or because performance analysis or optimization can be easily done in closed form or algorithmically. But we all recognize that there are trade-offs between the model's fidelity (i.e. their ability to replicate reality) and its tractability. This project investigates a systematic approach which can be used to account for the impact of this trade-off. The PI studies a wide range of models called stochastic networks, which are used to describe virtually any probabilistic system in which there is resource contention. These systems are used in logistics, transportation, communications and systemic risk, among others. The PI plans to apply the developed approach to study robustness questions related to stochastic networks in heavy-traffic utilization and rare events in such systems.
    
This project investigates a comprehensive set of tools which enables the quantification of model errors in the performance analysis and control of a wide range of stochastic systems. The investigator's strategy combines various areas of mathematics, including convex optimization, probability theory, and Monte Carlo methods. The investigator will exploit general duality results which are used to obtain explicit expressions for worst-case expectations among all probability models within a certain tolerance from a baseline probabilistic model (typically chosen for tractability). The metric describing the neighborhood of models is based on optimal transport theory. These results are applicable at the stochastic-process level (for random elements taken values on general Polish spaces), so they can be used to approximate sample-path expectations of complex stochastic systems. A key element in the program is that the worst-case probability of a given event can be expressed explicitly in terms of the probability of a modified (explicit) event under the baseline (tractable) model. The investigator will study a wide range of questions related to rare-event analysis and heavy-traffic approximations of stochastic networks, which are widely used in application areas such as communication networks, call centers, manufacturing systems, and chemical reaction networks, among others.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to investigate a comprehensive set of tools to enable robust performance analysis and decision making. The idea is to allow users to take advantage of so-called benchmark models that are computationally tractable but also accounting for the impact of potential model errors.  

In pursuit of this goal, the general framework proceeds by posing an infinite-dimensional convex optimization problem, in which nature chooses a non-parametric perturbation of the benchmark model. The perturbation is measured by assuming that nature is adversarial and is subject to a budget constraint. The solution of the adversarial optimization problem solved by nature is a worst-case bound of the expectation of interest. If the perturbation is null (i.e. nature's budget is zero), we recover the expectation under the assumed benchmark model. The no-budget case is precisely what is the current practice in which decision makers assume their models are corrent. 

In contrast to the current practice, the project enables a modeling cycle in which a benchmark model is coupled with a worst-case potential realizations via an infinite-dimensional problem (to maximize flexibility). We investigate how to solve the problem efficiently and in order to find a flexible worst-case adversarial probability distribution. The project obtained optimal algorithms to solve this infinite dimensional problem and the associated worst-case adversary in many settings of interest.

Examples of remarkable results obtained by the project include the following. First, the development of a data-driven method for estimating extreme quantiles in a manner that is robust against incorrect model assumptions underlying the application of standard statistical tools. This development illustrates examples in which the standard statistical theory of extremes can significantly underestimate quantiles of interest wheras the proposed method is able to identify correct coverages of extreme quantiles (even when the assumptions in the statistical theory of extremes are violated).

A second example involves the development of optimal algorithms for solutions of min-max games in which the decision maker (intending to minimize a cost) plays against nature (choosing a non-parametric distribution). The algorithms are shown to be optimal in the sense of achieving the same performance of well-known algorithms in stochastic optimization for cost minimization, even without including the adversarial player. 

Virtually any decision making problem which is subject to uncertainty involves assumptions which are subject to model error. Consequently, the results of this project can potentially benefit all areas in which these types of decision making problems under uncertainty arise. These areas include operations, health-care, transportation, economics, etc. So, the results of this project have the potential to significantly impact society. For instance, in the context of heavy investments in infrastructure, it is important to consider the fact that the environment in the future might be very different from the one that is modeled based on past observations. The results in this proposal are precisely designed to quantify these types of discrepancies. 

In addition, the proposal has contributed to the training of several Ph.D. students (two of which have successfully defended their dissertation - of them a female) and have joined the US workforce and the results form the basis for material that has been incorporated in courses at Stanford University - thus supporting the development of highly qualified human resources in the US.
